HE fight was now on in good earnest and T the Spaniards on the hills were engaged in heavy volley firing. The Mauser bullets drove in sheets through the trees and tall jungle grass, making a peculial· whirring , or rustling sound; some of the bullets seenied to pop in the air so that we thought they were explosive; and, indeed, many of those which where coated with brass did explode, in the ἲ sense that the brass coat was ripped off, making a thin plate of hard metal with a jagged edge, which inflicted a ghastly wound.

The shots were fired from rifles carrying smokeless powder, The Mauser hullets them- selves made a small clean holo, with the result that the wound healed in a most astonishing manner. One or two of our men who were shot in the head had the skull blown open, but elsewhere the wounds from the minute steel-coated bullet, with its very high velocity, were certainly nothing like as serious as those made by the old large-calibre, low-power rifle. If a man were shot through the heart, spine or brain, he was, of course, instantly killed3 but very few of the wounded died-even under the appaling conditions which pre- vailed‚ owing to the lack of attendance and supplies in the field-hospitals with the army.
